rev.diff:
Line 41: Line 41:
*Reports indicate that Van Schaick deserted the Slocum as soon as it ran aground, jumping into a nearby [[tug]], along with several crew. Some say his jacket was hardly rumpled.
*Reports indicate that Van Schaick deserted the Slocum as soon as it ran aground, jumping into a nearby [[tug]], along with several crew. Some say his jacket was hardly rumpled.
*All were dead within 2 hours of the blaze. 1021 dead, 421 survivors.
*All were dead within 2 hours of the blaze. 1021 dead, 421 survivors.
â
*Many died instantly when the 3-level floors of the overloaded liner collapsed, others were mauled by the still turning paddles or simply drowned because most could not swim and were clad in restrictive [[clothing]](1).
+
*Many died instantly when the 3-level floors of the overloaded liner collapsed, others were mauled by the still turning paddles or simply drowned because most could not swim and were clad in restrictive [[clothing]].<ref name=gentile>Gentile, "Shipwrecks of New Jersey", 2001</ref>
â
*President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] declined to pardon Captain Van Schaick, and he was not released until the federal parole board, under the [[William Howard Taft]] administration, voted to free him on August 26, 1911 (2).
+
*President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] declined to pardon Captain Van Schaick, and he was not released until the federal parole board, under the [[William Howard Taft]] administration, voted to free him on August 26, 1911.<ref name=robinson>Eric Robinson, New-York Historical Society Library</ref>
*As to why the unfortunate victims seemed to "sink" after landing in the [[water]], the Nash book suggests that the manager of the [[life preserver]] manufacturer actually placed [[iron]] bars inside the [[cork]] preservers to meet minimum weight requirements at the time. Managers of the company (Nonpareil Cork Works) were indicted, but not convicted. Many of the life preservers had been filled with cheap and less effective granulated cork and brought up to proper weight by the inclusion of the iron weights.
*As to why the unfortunate victims seemed to "sink" after landing in the [[water]], the Nash book suggests that the manager of the [[life preserver]] manufacturer actually placed [[iron]] bars inside the [[cork]] preservers to meet minimum weight requirements at the time. Managers of the company (Nonpareil Cork Works) were indicted, but not convicted. Many of the life preservers had been filled with cheap and less effective granulated cork and brought up to proper weight by the inclusion of the iron weights.
Line 56: Line 56:
*The 2005 [[Hugo award]] nominated novella "[[Time Ablaze]]" by [[Michael A. Burstein]] ([[Astounding magazine|''Analog'']], June 2004) concerns a time traveller who comes to record the disaster. The story was published to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the disaster.
*The 2005 [[Hugo award]] nominated novella "[[Time Ablaze]]" by [[Michael A. Burstein]] ([[Astounding magazine|''Analog'']], June 2004) concerns a time traveller who comes to record the disaster. The story was published to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the disaster.
*The General Slocum disaster was featured in the documentary ''My Father's Gun''.
*The General Slocum disaster was featured in the documentary ''My Father's Gun''.
